channel.title: Machine learning on Yuan Meng
channel.description: Recent content in Machine learning on Yuan Meng

item.title: MLE Interview 2.0: Research Engineering and Scary Rounds
item.author: mycaptainmy@gmail.com (Yuan Meng)
item.description:
Scary New Rounds

“Here goes nothing.” — Dustin Henderson, Stranger Things

I have always loved how Dustin from Stranger Things says “here goes nothing” before executing an impossible plan. According to Reddit, this phrase means “you have nothing left to lose” or that “even if it fails, you don’t lose anything of value”. That’s probably the mindset to have when interviewing with companies everybody wants to join.

item.title: ML Stuff I Wish to Learn (More) About in 2025
item.author: mycaptainmy@gmail.com (Yuan Meng)
item.description:
MLE friends and colleagues sometimes tell me about a sense of lack: how there’s so much to learn about the ML engineering craft — from mathematical foundations and deep learning history, to state-of-the-art research, industry gold standards, and the nitty-gritty engineering details — that it never feels like there’s time to go deep on anything.

Here’s how I see it: if you’ve kept your job (by delivering impact without getting fired), you’re already doing great. Hold on to who you (sidenote: In my case, I'm a pragmatic ML engineer curious about RecSys/LLM research, but I'm not an ML researcher or platform engineer.) and gradually foray into the unknowns that excite you — like opening a box of chocolates, take it one piece at a time and savor it.

item.title: (Opinionated) Guide to ML Engineer Job Hunting
item.author: mycaptainmy@gmail.com (Yuan Meng)
item.description:
The Marriage Analogy

Over 2 years ago, I wrote a blog post on how to find jobs as a new grad data scientist (as a twist of fate, I never worked as a product data scientist but instead became an ML engineer at DoorDash). Back in 2021, I cared a ton about interview skills, answer “frameworks”, and whatnot, which may still come handy at New Grad or Early Career levels. For experienced hires, however, I think of interviews as some sort of marriage proposal — it’s something you can rehearse but can never force.

item.title: Teaching A Peceptron to See
item.author: mycaptainmy@gmail.com (Yuan Meng)
item.description: Ten years after the ImageNet Challenge thawed the last AI winter, ChaptGPT and generative AI have become part of our everyday life and colloquial language, like (almost) no one has imagined just 2 years back. As increasingly more folks aspire to foray into the field of ML/AI, I can’t help but think about a lesson from my guitar teacher:

item.title: Code ML Algorithms From Scratch
item.author: mycaptainmy@gmail.com (Yuan Meng)
item.description: Coding interviews can mean different things for “traditional” software engineers (back-end, front-end, full-stack, etc.) and engineers with a machine learning focus. Apart from LeetCode-style questions, ML engineers (as well as applied scientists, research engineers, and, occasionally, machine learning data scientists) may be asked to implement a classic ML algorithm from scratch during an interview.

item.title: (Quirky) Roadmap for New Grad Data Scientists
item.author: mycaptainmy@gmail.com (Yuan Meng)
item.description:
New Grad Timeline

Since last November, I regularly get questions about how to get data science jobs. I’ve hesitated to give advice because no advice applies to everyone. As more people ask, however, I want to write a post for those in my shoes:

(PhD) students applying to machine learning or product data scientist roles at tech companies through university recruiting.
